profileText: A Senator from North Dakota; born on a farm in Everest Township, near Casselton, Cass County, N.Dak., September 30, 1886; attended the rural schools; graduated from the law department of the University of North Dakota at Grand Forks in 1906 and from Columbia University, New York City in 1910; admitted to the bar in 1911 and began practice in Mandan, N.Dak.; State's attorney of Morton County, N.Dak., 1914-1916; moved to Bismarck, N.Dak., in 1916 and continued the practice of law; attorney general of North Dakota 1916-1920; legal adviser for Council of Defense during the First World War; unsuccessful candidate for Governor in 1920; Governor of North Dakota January 1933 to July 1934, when he was removed by the State supreme court; again Governor 1937-1939; unsuccessful candidate for nomination for United States Senator in 1938; elected as a Republican to the United States Senate in 1940; though there was an attempt to block his seating, Langer took his seat in the Senate in 1941; reelected in 1946, 1952, and again in 1958, and served from January 3, 1941, until his death in Washington, D.C., November 8, 1959; chairman, Committee on the Post Office and Civil Service (Eightieth Congress), Committee on the Judiciary (Eighty-third Congress); lay in state in the Senate chamber November 10, 1959; interment in St. Leo's Catholic Cemetery, Casselton, N.Dak.

researchRecord.name: Correspondence in Arthur Hendrick Vandenberg papers, 1884-1974; and Blair Moody papers, 1928-1954. Finding aid.
In Harry Lashkowitz papers, 1912-1962; Oscar J. Sorlie papers, 1919-1941; Martin O. Thompson papers, 1906-1948; and Oliver Rosenberg papers, 1933-1954. Finding aid.

1900-1959. 936 linear feet. Personal, business, political and legal correspondence and papers; material concerning service as state's attorney for Morton County; correspondence as attorney general; gubernatorial files; and senatorial materials. Senatorial files include office correspondence, subject files, legislative files, speeches, clippings, and 9 photographs. Also includes photocopies of Witness Books (1940) on the seating of Langer in the Senate, originals in the Committee on Privileges and Elections records at the National Archives. Senatorial files include information on Missouri River Diversion project, Rural Electrification Administration, North Dakota post offices, various farm programs, and document his work on several committees.

Cartoons (1934) in Minnie D. Craig papers, 1919-1934; in Joseph B. Bridston papers, 1939-1963; material relating to attempted unseating (1941) of Langer in Halvor L. Halvorson papers, 1939-1948; correspondence in Donald C. MacDonald papers, 1895-1969; copy of transcript of U.S. v. William Langer (1933-1935) in North Dakota politics: trial transcripts collection, 1917-1935; and campaign posters in political poster collection, 1914-1940.
